com.mwdiamond.fansi

Class AnsiUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mwdiamond.fansi.AnsiUtils

  • public class AnsiUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    High-level utility class for common tasks involving ANSI output.

    Features:

    • Updatable progress bars for percentages or items
    • Message Templates:
      • Status messages: [ OK ], [ WARN ], [ ERROR ]
      • Event / logging messages: [ INFO ], [ WARN ], [ ERROR ], [ DEBUG ]
      • Task results: [ DONE ], [ PASS ], [ SKIP ], [ FAIL ]

    This class can be safely persisted and most usages can simply share one instance across the entire application. Like the Ansi class individual methods are not thread-safe, however, and external synchronization should be used if multiple threads will be writing output concurrently.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  AnsiUtils.ProgressBar
      A text progress bar that will overwrite itself when updated, presenting the user with dynamic yet concise visualization of the application's current progress.

      • ok

        public void ok(java.lang.String message,
               java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ OK ] block. Generally used to indicate a good status (as opposed to a successful task; prefer pass() or done() for that).
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        warn(), error()

      • done

        public void done(java.lang.String message,
                 java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ DONE ] block. Generally used to indicate a successfully completed task. Prefer ok() when reporting a good status.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        pass(), skip(), fail()

      • pass

        public void pass(java.lang.String message,
                 java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ PASS ] block. Generally used to indicate a successfully completed task such as a passing test. Prefer ok() when reporting a good status.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        done(), skip(), fail()

        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message

        warn(), error(), debug()

      • warn

        public void warn(java.lang.String message,
                 java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ WARN ] block. Generally used to inform the user of an unexpected but recoverable event or status.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        ok(), info(), error(), debug()

      • skip

        public void skip(java.lang.String message,
                 java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ SKIP ] block. Generally used to indicate a task was not attempted in order to avoid failing. Prefer warn() when reporting an unexpected but recoverable status or event.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        done(), pass(), fail()

      • fail

        public void fail(java.lang.String message,
                 java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with stylized a [ FAIL ] block. Generally used to indicate a task failed to complete successfully. Prefer error() when reporting a serious unexpected status or event.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        done(), pass(), skip()

      • error

        public void error(java.lang.String message,
                  java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes a message to stdout along with a stylized [ ERROR ] block. Generally used to inform the user of an unexpected status or event that cannot be (easily) recovered from. Prefer fail() for tasks that have failed.
        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        info(), warn(), debug()

        Parameters:
        message - the message to display
        args - (optionally) arguments to format into the message
        See Also:
        info(), warn(), error()

      • progressBarBuilder

        public AnsiUtils.ProgressBar.Builder progressBarBuilder()
        Returns a builder to configure a custom AnsiUtils.ProgressBar. Most users can simply use percentProgressBar() or counterProgressBar(int), but more options are available via the builder.

        For example, the following code: 

         ProgressBar customProgressBar = ansiUtil.progressBarBuilder()
     .prefix("<")
     .suffix(">")
     .barCharacter('-')
     .units(" tasks")
     .usingCounter(10);

        Would result in a progress bar that looks like: 

         <------------------------                          > 5/10 tasks
        Returns:
        a builder to construct AnsiUtils.ProgressBar instances.

      • percentProgressBar

        public AnsiUtils.ProgressBar percentProgressBar()
        Returns a ProgressBar that will display a percentage. Users will generally call AnsiUtils.ProgressBar.updateProgress(int) to update the percentage to display, however they can also use AnsiUtils.ProgressBar.updateSteps(int, int) to let the ProgressBar convert the current step into a percentage.

        This method simply constructs the ProgressBar, nothing is written to the console.

        Example: 

         [=============================                            ] 50%
        Returns:
        a AnsiUtils.ProgressBar instance starting at 0 percent complete

      • counterProgressBar

        public AnsiUtils.ProgressBar counterProgressBar(int initialStepCount)
        Returns a ProgressBar that will display an x/y counter. The initialStepCount is the number of steps that will need to be taken to fill the bar. It can be updated later via updateSteps().

        This method simply constructs the ProgressBar, nothing is written to the console.

        Example: 

         [===========================                           ] 50/100
        Parameters:
        initialStepCount - The number of steps to fill the progress bar
        Returns:
        a AnsiUtils.ProgressBar instance starting at 0 steps complete

      • counterProgressBar

        public AnsiUtils.ProgressBar counterProgressBar(int initialStepCount,
                                                java.lang.String units)
        Returns a ProgressBar that will display an x/y counter. The initialStepCount is the number of steps that will need to be taken to fill the bar. It can be updated later via updateSteps().

        This method simply constructs the ProgressBar, nothing is written to the console.

        Example (units: " tasks"): 

         [========================                        ] 50/100 tasks
        Parameters:
        initialStepCount - The number of steps to fill the progress bar
        units - text appended to the counter as the progress bar's units, e.g. "%" or " tasks"
        Returns:
        a AnsiUtils.ProgressBar instance starting at 0 steps complete and using the given units
